abstract: Four-judge panel in Argentina convicts 14 former military officers for their roles in Operation Condor, plan devised by six South American military governments in 1970s and '80s to eliminate leftist dissidents; defendants, most of whom are already serving time for other human rights violations, received prison terms of eight to 25 years, including Reynaldo Bignone, Argentina's last military dictator.

headline.print_headline: Argentine Court Confirms a Deadly Legacy of Dictatorships
headline.main: Argentine Court Confirms a Deadly Legacy of Dictatorships

keywords.value: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
keywords.name: subject

keywords.value: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
keywords.name: subject

snippet: Several former officers were sentenced for their role in regionwide kidnappings, torture and murders during an era of South American military dictatorships in the 1970s and ’80s.
lead_paragraph: Several former officers were sentenced for their role in regionwide kidnappings, torture and murders during an era of South American military dictatorships in the 1970s and ’80s.
